details.overview: In Work Credit for lone parents leaving benefits and starting work or self-employment - up to £60 a week, claim form, eligibility

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
You could get up to £60 a week In Work Credit if you’re a single parent and you stop claiming benefit because you’re starting work or self-employment.

You have to qualify, and apply for In Work Credit within 5 weeks of starting work or self-employment.

Any money you get isn’t taxed and won’t affect your other benefits.

You must have started claiming a qualifying benefit on or before 1 October 2012.

parts.title: What you'll get
parts.body:
You’ll get:

  • £40 a week if you live outside London
  • £60 a week if you live in London

Jobcentre Plus can tell you if you qualify as living in London for In Work Credit.

Usually, you keep getting In Work Credit if you carry on working 16 hours or more a week (on average).

Payments can last for 12 months, but will stop on 1 October 2013.

How you’re paid

All benefits, pensions and allowances are paid into an account, eg your bank account.

parts.title: Eligibility
parts.body:
To qualify for In Work Credit you must:

  • be a single parent with a child under 16
  • start your job before 1 October 2013
  • expect your job to last at least 5 weeks
  • work at least 16 or more hours a week
  • earn at least the National Minimum Wage
  • stop claiming a ‘qualifying benefit’
  • go straight from claiming the benefit to starting your job
  • claim it within 5 weeks of starting your job

‘Work’ can include self-employment.

Qualifying benefits

You must have:

  • claimed a qualifying benefit for at least 52 weeks
  • started claiming the qualifying benefit before 1 October 2012

London

To qualify, you must stop getting one of these benefits before you start work:

  • Employment and Support Allowance
  • Incapacity Benefit
  • Severe Disablement Allowance

Outside London

To qualify, you must stop getting one of these benefits before you start work:

  • Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • Income Support
  • Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) because your child is too old for you to keep getting ESA

Your Employment and Support Allowance won’t qualify if you got it because:

  • you were too ill to qualify for Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • your child was too old for you to qualify for Income Support

Exceptions

You might still qualify if:

  • you’re getting Carer’s Allowance and stopping one of the qualifying benefits
  • your partner was claiming Jobseeker’s Allowance or Income Support

Ask your local Jobcentre Plus if you qualify when you tell them you’ve started your job.

parts.title: How to claim
parts.body:
Within 5 weeks of starting work contact your local Jobcentre Plus and ask for an In Work Credit claim form.

You must have started working on or before 30 September 2013.
